lessons.title: 423. Reading environment variables
lessons.description: Learn how to read environment variables using System.getenv() in Java
lessons.expectedOutput:
PATH exists: true
User: [username]
Total environment variables: [count]
lessons.tutorial:
Reading Environment Variables in Java

Environment variables are key-value pairs provided by the operating system that allow configuration without changing code.

Basic Usage

Read a single environment variable: 
String path = System.getenv("PATH");
if (path != null) {
    System.out.println("PATH: " + path);
} else {
    System.out.println("PATH not set");
}

Reading All Variables

Get all environment variables as a Map: 
Map env = System.getenv();
for (Map.Entry entry : env.entrySet()) {
    System.out.println(entry.getKey() + " = " + entry.getValue());
}

Cross-Platform Variable Names

Different operating systems use different variable names: 
// Get username (cross-platform)
String user = System.getenv("USER");  // Unix/Linux/Mac
if (user == null) {
    user = System.getenv("USERNAME");  // Windows
}
System.out.println("Current user: " + user);
// Get home directory
String home = System.getenv("HOME");  // Unix
if (home == null) {
    home = System.getenv("USERPROFILE");  // Windows
}

Common Environment Variables

  • PATH: Directories to search for executables
  • HOME (Unix) / USERPROFILE (Windows): User's home directory
  • USER (Unix) / USERNAME (Windows): Current username
  • JAVA_HOME: Java installation directory
  • TEMP / TMP: Temporary files directory

Best Practices

  • Always check for null: Variables may not be set
  • Handle platform differences: Use fallback logic for OS-specific variables
  • Don't rely on case: Variable names are case-sensitive on Unix, case-insensitive on Windows
  • Security: Never log sensitive environment variables (API keys, passwords)

When to Use

  • Reading system configuration
  • Detecting runtime environment
  • Finding system directories
  • Getting user information
  • CI/CD pipeline configuration

lessons.title: 424. Default environment variable values
lessons.description: Learn how to provide default values for environment variables
lessons.expectedOutput:
App: MyApp
Port: 8080
Log Level: INFO
lessons.tutorial:
Default Environment Variable Values in Java

Providing default values makes your application more robust and easier to configure.

Reading with Defaults

The basic pattern for environment variables with defaults: 
private static String getEnvOrDefault(String name, String defaultValue) {
    String value = System.getenv(name);
    return value != null ? value : defaultValue;
}
// Usage
String appName = getEnvOrDefault("APP_NAME", "MyApp");
String port = getEnvOrDefault("PORT", "8080");

Type Conversion

Since environment variables are always strings, you need to convert them: 
// Integer
int port = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("PORT", "8080"));
// Boolean
boolean debug = Boolean.parseBoolean(getEnvOrDefault("DEBUG", "false"));
// With error handling
int timeout;
try {
    timeout = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("TIMEOUT", "30"));
} catch (NumberFormatException e) {
    timeout = 30; // fallback default
}

Configuration Class Pattern

For complex applications, create a configuration class: 
public class AppConfig {
    public static final String APP_NAME = getEnvOrDefault("APP_NAME", "MyApp");
    public static final int PORT = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("PORT", "8080"));
    public static final String LOG_LEVEL = getEnvOrDefault("LOG_LEVEL", "INFO");
    private static String getEnvOrDefault(String name, String defaultValue) {
        String value = System.getenv(name);
        return value != null ? value : defaultValue;
    }
}

Best Practices

  • Document all variables: Maintain a README or .env.example file listing all expected environment variables
  • Use sensible defaults: Development-friendly defaults reduce configuration burden
  • Validate after parsing: Check that converted values are in acceptable ranges
  • Fail fast: For required variables without good defaults, fail early with clear error messages

When to Use

  • Configuring server ports, database URLs, API keys
  • Feature flags and debug modes
  • Environment-specific settings (dev/staging/prod)
  • Docker and cloud deployments

Example: Complete Configuration

public class DatabaseConfig {
    private final String host;
    private final int port;
    private final String database;
    public DatabaseConfig() {
        this.host = getEnvOrDefault("DB_HOST", "localhost");
        this.port = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("DB_PORT", "5432"));
        this.database = getEnvOrDefault("DB_NAME", "myapp");
        validate();
    }
    private void validate() {
        if (port < 1 || port > 65535) {
            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid port: " + port);
        }
    }
    private static String getEnvOrDefault(String name, String defaultValue) {
        String value = System.getenv(name);
        return value != null ? value : defaultValue;
    }
}

lessons.title: 425. Logger with multiple levels
lessons.description: Learn how to use different logging levels in Java
lessons.expectedOutput:
SEVERE: This is a SEVERE message
WARNING: This is a WARNING message
INFO: This is an INFO message
Check console for log messages
lessons.tutorial:
Java's logging framework provides a hierarchical system for tracking application behavior, debugging issues, and monitoring production systems. The java.util.logging package offers five primary logging levels (SEVERE, WARNING, INFO, CONFIG, FINE) that help developers categorize message importance. Understanding logging levels is crucial for effective debugging and system monitoring in enterprise applications where you need to track what's happening across distributed components.

Basic Pattern

import java.util.logging.;
Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(MyClass.class.getName());
logger.severe("Critical error occurred");
logger.warning("Potential issue detected");
logger.info("Normal operation message");

Advanced Usage

import java.util.logging.;
public class LoggerDemo {
    private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(LoggerDemo.class.getName());
    static {
        logger.setLevel(Level.ALL);
        ConsoleHandler handler = new ConsoleHandler();
        handler.setLevel(Level.ALL);
        logger.addHandler(handler);
        logger.setUseParentHandlers(false);
    }
    public void processData(String data) {
        logger.fine("Processing started: " + data);
        logger.config("Configuration loaded");
        logger.info("Data processed successfully");
    }
}

Complete Example

import java.util.logging.*;
public class Main {
    private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(Main.class.getName());
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            logger.info("Application started");
            int result = divide(10, 0);
            logger.info("Result: " + result);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            logger.severe("Exception occurred: " + e.getMessage());
            logger.warning("Using default value");
        } finally {
            logger.info("Application shutdown");
        }
    }
    static int divide(int a, int b) {
        logger.fine("Dividing " + a + " by " + b);
        return a / b;
    }
}

Common Use Cases

  • Error tracking: Log exceptions and error conditions with SEVERE level for immediate attention
  • Debugging production issues: Use INFO and FINE levels to trace application flow without overwhelming logs
  • Performance monitoring: Track operation timing and resource usage with appropriate log levels
  • Audit trails: Record user actions and system events for compliance and security analysis

Best Practices

  • Use appropriate log levels consistently across your application (SEVERE for errors, WARNING for issues, INFO for milestones)
  • Include contextual information in log messages (user IDs, transaction IDs, timestamps)
  • Configure log levels externally via properties files rather than hard-coding in source
  • Avoid logging sensitive data (passwords, credit cards, personal information)
  • Use parameterized logging for better performance: logger.log(Level.INFO, "User {0} logged in", userId)

When to Use

Use Java logging when building production applications that require monitoring and debugging capabilities, when you need hierarchical logger control across modules, when compliance requires audit trails, or when you're working in enterprise environments with centralized logging systems. Logging is essential for diagnosing issues in deployed applications where debuggers aren't available.

lessons.title: 426. Custom log formatter
lessons.description: Learn how to create custom log formatters in Java
lessons.expectedOutput:
[2024-01-15 10:30:45] INFO: Application started
[2024-01-15 10:30:45] WARNING: This is a warning
lessons.tutorial:
Custom log formatters in Java allow precise control over log output format, including timestamps, thread information, log levels, and message content. The java.util.logging.Formatter abstract class provides the foundation for creating formatters, with SimpleFormatter and XMLFormatter as built-in implementations. Creating custom formatters enables consistent logging across enterprise applications and integration with log aggregation systems like ELK stack or Splunk.

Basic Pattern

import java.util.logging.;
public class SimpleCustomFormatter extends Formatter {
    @Override
    public String format(LogRecord record) {
        return String.format("[%s] %s: %s%n",
            record.getLevel(),
            record.getLoggerName(),
            record.getMessage()
        );
    }
}
// Usage
Logger logger = Logger.getLogger("MyLogger");
ConsoleHandler handler = new ConsoleHandler();
handler.setFormatter(new SimpleCustomFormatter());
logger.addHandler(handler);

Advanced Usage

import java.util.logging.;
import java.time.;
import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter;
public class DetailedFormatter extends Formatter {
    private static final DateTimeFormatter formatter =
        DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.SSS");
    @Override
    public String format(LogRecord record) {
        LocalDateTime timestamp = LocalDateTime.ofInstant(
            Instant.ofEpochMilli(record.getMillis()),
            ZoneId.systemDefault()
        );
        return String.format("%s | %s | %s | %s.%s | %s%n",
            timestamp.format(formatter),
            Thread.currentThread().getName(),
            record.getLevel(),
            record.getSourceClassName(),
            record.getSourceMethodName(),
            record.getMessage()
        );
    }
}

Complete Example

import java.util.logging.;
import java.io.PrintWriter;
import java.io.StringWriter;
public class Main {
    static class JsonFormatter extends Formatter {
        @Override
        public String format(LogRecord record) {
            StringBuilder json = new StringBuilder("{");
            json.append("\"timestamp\":").append(record.getMillis()).append(",");
            json.append("\"level\":\"").append(record.getLevel()).append("\",");
            json.append("\"logger\":\"").append(record.getLoggerName()).append("\",");
            json.append("\"message\":\"").append(escape(record.getMessage())).append("\"");
            if (record.getThrown() != null) {
                StringWriter sw = new StringWriter();
                record.getThrown().printStackTrace(new PrintWriter(sw));
                json.append(",\"exception\":\"").append(escape(sw.toString())).append("\"");
            }
            json.append("}\n");
            return json.toString();
        }
        private String escape(String str) {
            return str.replace("\\", "\\\\").replace("\"", "\\\"").replace("\n", "\\n");
        }
    }
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(Main.class.getName());
        ConsoleHandler handler = new ConsoleHandler();
        handler.setFormatter(new JsonFormatter());
        logger.addHandler(handler);
        logger.setUseParentHandlers(false);
        logger.info("Application started");
        logger.warning("Low memory detected");
        try {
            throw new RuntimeException("Test exception");
        } catch (Exception e) {
            logger.log(Level.SEVERE, "Error occurred", e);
        }
    }
}

Common Use Cases

  • JSON logging: Format logs as JSON for easy parsing by log aggregation tools like ELK stack
  • Structured logging: Include metadata fields (user ID, request ID, session ID) in consistent format
  • Console output: Create human-readable formats for development with color coding and alignment
  • Integration with monitoring: Format logs to match requirements of monitoring systems like Splunk or Datadog

Best Practices

  • Keep format() method thread-safe as it may be called concurrently from multiple threads
  • Cache expensive objects like DateTimeFormatter instances as class-level static fields
  • Include essential context (timestamp, level, logger name) in every formatted message
  • Escape special characters properly when generating JSON, XML, or CSV formatted logs
  • Consider performance impact of complex formatting; use buffered output for high-volume logging

When to Use

Use custom formatters when integrating with centralized logging infrastructure, when you need machine-parseable log formats (JSON, XML), when building microservices that require consistent log formats across services, or when existing formatters don't provide needed information. Custom formatters are essential for production systems with sophisticated monitoring and alerting requirements.
